docs.lead_paragraph: It's party time, and in homes, offices, restaurants and bars throughout America, the drinks are flowing more freely than usual. Alcohol, the nation's favorite mood-altering drug, is sup posed to make people feel good and friendly to ease social interactions, loosen tongues and spirits, and warm the body if not the soul. Many consider it an ideal perhaps even an essential accompaniment to holiday and other celebrations.

headline.main: PERSONAL HEALTH; Holiday Drinking, But No Morning After Personal Health

docs.abstract: Article advises partygoers on how to reduce effect of alcohol; chart; illus (M)
docs.snippet: It's party time, and in homes, offices, restaurants and bars throughout America, the drinks are flowing more freely than usual. Alcohol, the nation's favorite mood-altering drug, is sup  posed to make people feel good and friendly to ease social...

docs.lead_paragraph: TYLER, Tex. Dec. 13 William Morris, a 50-year-old former asbestos worker, is afraid that he is dying. And he is angry, because for years neither his employer nor visiting Federal health inspectors warned him that clouds of dust he was sucking into his lungs at work caused cancer.

headline.main: Asbestos Workers' Illness and Their Suit May Change Health Standards

docs.abstract: Suit by over 400 asbestos workers against Fed Govt and various cos to be settled for $20-million, without trial; does not set legal precedent but may prompt changes in enforcement of Fed occupational health regulations; workers charged employers and Fed inspectors wrongfully did not inform them of hazards of working with asbestos; many have contacted lung cancer and asbestosis as result; suit background detailed (M)

byline.original: By DAVID BURNHAM Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: NEWARK, Dec. 14 (UPI)--Four independent pharmacies have sued New Jersey Blue Cross for allegedly fixing prices through a prepaid prescription drug insurance program.

headline.main: 4 JERSEY PHARMACIES SUE BLUE CROSS IN U.S. COURT

docs.abstract: 4 ind pharmacies sue NJ Blue Cross for allegedly fixing prices through prepaid prescription drug ins program; charge plan prevents natural competition and diverts business; say plan undercut prices of pharmacies refusing to participate in program; 4 stores listed (S)
docs.snippet: NEWARK, Dec. 14 (UPI)--Four independent pharmacies have sued New Jersey Blue Cross for allegedly fixing prices through a prepaid prescription drug insurance program.
